canonical_explanation.text: Chemistry in everyday life covers the application of chemical knowledge to drugs, food additives, cleansing agents, and other materials used daily. Drugs are chemicals of low molecular mass that interact with biological macromolecular targets to produce a therapeutic response. They are classified based on pharmacological effect (analgesics, antiseptics, etc.), drug action (mechanism), chemical structure, or molecular targets. Drug-target interaction: drugs interact with specific biological macromolecules such as enzymes and receptors. Enzyme inhibitors can be competitive (bind to active site, compete with substrate) or non-competitive (bind to allosteric site, change enzyme shape). Receptor-drug interaction occurs when drugs bind to receptor proteins on cell surfaces, mimicking or blocking the natural chemical messenger. Agonists mimic and activate the receptor; antagonists block the receptor. Analgesics relieve pain without causing loss of consciousness: non-narcotic analgesics (aspirin, ibuprofen, paracetamol) work by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis; narcotic analgesics (morphine, codeine, heroin) act on the central nervous system and are addictive. Tranquilizers are neurologically active drugs that reduce anxiety and mental tension without inducing sleep: barbiturates (veronal, seconal, luminal), benzodiazepines (diazepam/valium, chlordiazepoxide/librium), and others like equanil. Antiseptics are applied to living tissues to prevent infection (e.g., Dettol which contains chloroxylenol, iodine tincture, boric acid, hydrogen peroxide); disinfectants are applied to non-living surfaces (e.g., phenol 1% solution, chlorine in water treatment). The same substance can be an antiseptic at low concentration and a disinfectant at high concentration (e.g., phenol: 0.2% is antiseptic, 1% is disinfectant). Antimicrobials/antibiotics kill or inhibit microorganisms: bactericidal antibiotics kill bacteria (penicillin, ofloxacin, aminoglycosides); bacteriostatic antibiotics inhibit growth (erythromycin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol). Broad-spectrum antibiotics work against a wide range of bacteria; narrow-spectrum target specific types. Antifertility drugs contain synthetic progestogens and oestrogens that prevent ovulation: examples include norethindrone, ethynylestradiol (used in birth control pills). Antacids neutralise excess stomach acid: examples include aluminium hydroxide, magnesium hydroxide, and sodium hydrogen carbonate. Antihistamines block histamine receptors to relieve allergy symptoms: examples include brompheniramine, terfenadine, cimetidine (anti-ulcer, H2 receptor blocker). Food chemistry: artificial sweeteners include aspartame (200 times sweeter than sucrose), saccharin (550 times sweeter), sucralose, and alitame; they provide sweetness without calories. Food preservatives prevent spoilage: sodium benzoate (most common), sodium metabisulphite (SO2 source), potassium sorbate, and salt/sugar/vinegar (traditional). Antioxidants in food prevent oxidative rancidity: BHT (butylated hydroxytoluene) and BHA (butylated hydroxyanisole) are synthetic antioxidants; vitamin C and vitamin E are natural antioxidants. Soaps are sodium or potassium salts of long-chain fatty acids (e.g., sodium stearate, sodium palmitate), made by saponification (alkaline hydrolysis) of fats/oils. They work by forming micelles: the non-polar hydrocarbon tail dissolves in grease and the polar head faces water, emulsifying dirt. Soaps do not work in hard water because they form insoluble calcium and magnesium salts (scum). Synthetic detergents are sodium salts of long-chain alkyl sulphates or sulphonates (anionic detergents), quaternary ammonium salts (cationic detergents), or polyethylene glycol stearates (non-ionic detergents). They work in hard water because their calcium/magnesium salts are soluble. Biodegradable detergents have straight-chain hydrocarbon tails; non-biodegradable detergents have branched chains.
rules: Drugs interact with specific biological targets: enzymes (competitive or non-competitive inhibition) and receptors (agonists activate, antagonists block).
Analgesics: non-narcotic (aspirin, paracetamol) inhibit prostaglandin synthesis; narcotic (morphine) act on CNS and are addictive.
Antiseptics are for living tissues; disinfectants are for non-living surfaces. Phenol: 0.2% antiseptic, 1% disinfectant.
Antibiotics: bactericidal (kill bacteria, e.g., penicillin) vs bacteriostatic (inhibit growth, e.g., erythromycin); broad-spectrum vs narrow-spectrum.
Antifertility drugs contain synthetic progestogens and oestrogens to suppress ovulation.
Artificial sweeteners (aspartame, saccharin) provide sweetness without calories; useful for diabetics and weight control.
Food preservatives (sodium benzoate, sodium metabisulphite) prevent microbial growth; antioxidants (BHT, BHA) prevent oxidative rancidity.
Soaps are sodium/potassium salts of fatty acids; they fail in hard water by forming insoluble scum with Ca2+/Mg2+ ions.
Detergents are sodium salts of alkyl sulphates/sulphonates; they work in hard water because their Ca/Mg salts are soluble.
Biodegradable detergents have straight-chain tails; non-biodegradable detergents have branched chains that resist microbial breakdown.

questions.question_text: Aspirin is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is a non-narcotic analgesic that relieves pain by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins. It is also an antipyretic (reduces fever) and anti-inflammatory drug.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Narcotic analgesics include morphine and heroin. Tranquilizers reduce anxiety (e.g., diazepam). Antibiotics fight bacterial infections (e.g., penicillin). Aspirin is specifically a non-narcotic analgesic.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a narcotic analgesic?
questions.explanation_correct: Morphine is a narcotic analgesic that acts on the central nervous system to relieve severe pain. It is obtained from opium poppy and is highly addictive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paracetamol, ibuprofen, and aspirin are non-narcotic analgesics that work peripherally by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. They are not addictive.

questions.question_text: An antiseptic differs from a disinfectant in that an antiseptic is:

options.text: Applied to living tissues to prevent infection
Always more concentrated than a disinfectant

questions.explanation_correct: Antiseptics are antimicrobial substances applied to living tissues (skin, wounds) to prevent infection. Disinfectants are applied to non-living surfaces (floors, instruments) to kill microbes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Disinfectants, not antiseptics, are applied to non-living surfaces. Antiseptics are usually more dilute, not more concentrated. Antiseptics are topical agents, different from systemic antibiotics.

questions.question_text: Dettol is an antiseptic that contains:
questions.explanation_correct: Dettol is a well-known antiseptic containing chloroxylenol (a chlorinated phenol derivative) and terpineol. It is used for cleaning wounds and as a general antiseptic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boric acid is a mild antiseptic used for eyes. Iodine in alcohol is tincture of iodine. Hydrogen peroxide is a different antiseptic. Dettol specifically contains chloroxylenol.

questions.question_text: Penicillin is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Penicillin is an antibiotic discovered by Alexander Fleming. It is bactericidal (kills bacteria) by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis. It was the first widely used antibiotic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Analgesics relieve pain, tranquilizers reduce anxiety, and antihistamines treat allergies. Penicillin specifically fights bacterial infections.

questions.question_text: A bacteriostatic antibiotic is one that:

options.text: Inhibits the growth and reproduction of bacteria without killing them

questions.explanation_correct: Bacteriostatic antibiotics (e.g., erythromycin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol) inhibit bacterial growth and multiplication without directly killing the bacteria. The immune system then clears the weakened bacteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Killing bacteria directly is bactericidal action. Antibiotics generally do not work against viruses. Antifungals, not antibiotics, target fungi specifically.

questions.question_text: Phenol is used as an antiseptic at 0.2% concentration. At 1% concentration, it acts as:
questions.explanation_correct: Phenol at 0.2% is used as an antiseptic for living tissues. At higher concentration (1%), it is too harsh for living tissues and is used as a disinfectant for non-living surfaces like floors and drains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phenol is not an analgesic, tranquilizer, or antibiotic. The same chemical substance can serve as either antiseptic or disinfectant depending on the concentration.

questions.question_text: Tranquilizers are used to treat:

options.text: Mental diseases like anxiety, tension, and insomnia

questions.explanation_correct: Tranquilizers are psychotherapeutic drugs used to treat mental diseases like anxiety, tension, insomnia, and other mental disorders. Examples include diazepam (Valium), chlordiazepoxide (Librium), and barbiturates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotics treat bacterial infections. Analgesics treat pain and fever. Antihistamines treat allergies. Tranquilizers specifically target mental and psychological conditions.

questions.question_text: Antifertility drugs work by:

options.text: Containing synthetic progestogens and oestrogens that suppress ovulation
Preventing implantation by changing blood pH

questions.explanation_correct: Antifertility drugs (oral contraceptives) contain synthetic progestogens (like norethindrone) and oestrogens (like ethynylestradiol). These hormones suppress ovulation by modifying the hormonal balance that triggers egg release.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They do not kill sperm, destroy the uterine lining, or change blood pH. Their primary mechanism is hormonal suppression of ovulation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a broad-spectrum antibiotic?
questions.explanation_correct: Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, as well as some rickettsiae. It was one of the first broad-spectrum antibiotics discovered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Penicillin G is relatively narrow-spectrum (mainly Gram-positive). Dysidazirine is an antifungal/antitumour compound. Salvarsan was the first modern antimicrobial but is not broad-spectrum.

questions.question_text: Equanil is used as:

options.text: An analgesic and an antifertility drug
A tranquilizer and a muscle relaxant

questions.explanation_correct: Equanil (meprobamate) is used as a tranquilizer for treating anxiety and tension. It also has muscle relaxant properties and is used to control muscle spasms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equanil is not an analgesic, antifertility drug, antiseptic, disinfectant, antibiotic, or antimalarial. It is specifically a tranquilizer with muscle relaxant action.

questions.question_text: Antacids work by:

options.text: Neutralising excess hydrochloric acid in the stomach
Coating the stomach wall with a polymer

questions.explanation_correct: Antacids are basic compounds (e.g., Al(OH)3, Mg(OH)2, NaHCO3) that neutralise excess HCl in the stomach, relieving acidity, heartburn, and indigestion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antacids do not kill bacteria (antibiotics do that). They reduce acid, not increase it. They do not form polymer coatings.

questions.question_text: Cimetidine is an example of:

options.text: Antihistamine (H2 receptor blocker used as anti-ulcer drug)

questions.explanation_correct: Cimetidine is an H2 receptor blocker (antihistamine). It blocks histamine H2 receptors in the stomach lining, reducing acid secretion. It is used to treat peptic ulcers and gastroesophageal reflux.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cimetidine is not a pain reliever (analgesic), anxiety reducer (tranquilizer), or birth control drug (antifertility). It specifically targets stomach acid secretion.

questions.question_text: In competitive inhibition of an enzyme, the inhibitor:

options.text: Binds to the allosteric site and changes enzyme shape
Competes with the substrate for the active site of the enzyme

questions.explanation_correct: In competitive inhibition, the drug molecule competes with the natural substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. The inhibitor has a similar shape to the substrate and blocks it from binding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Allosteric site binding is non-competitive inhibition. Competitive inhibitors do not permanently destroy the enzyme (they bind reversibly). They decrease, not increase, enzyme activity.

questions.question_text: Receptors in drug-target interaction are:

options.text: Small molecules that bind to drugs
Proteins embedded in cell membranes that receive chemical signals
Nucleic acids inside the cell nucleus

questions.explanation_correct: Receptors are proteins (often embedded in cell membranes) that have specific binding sites for chemical messengers (hormones, neurotransmitters). When a drug binds to a receptor, it triggers or blocks a cellular response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Receptors are not small molecules, nucleic acids, or lipids. They are specifically proteins with binding sites that receive and transmit chemical signals.

questions.question_text: A drug that mimics the natural chemical messenger and activates a receptor is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An agonist is a drug that binds to a receptor and mimics the effect of the natural chemical messenger, activating the receptor and producing a biological response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An antagonist blocks the receptor without activating it. An inhibitor reduces enzyme activity. A catalyst speeds up chemical reactions. Only agonists mimic and activate.

questions.question_text: In non-competitive enzyme inhibition, the inhibitor:

options.text: Binds to the active site of the enzyme
Binds to a site other than the active site, changing the enzyme shape so the substrate cannot fit
Binds to the substrate instead of the enzyme

questions.explanation_correct: Non-competitive inhibitors bind to the allosteric site (a site different from the active site) on the enzyme. This changes the shape of the enzyme, particularly the active site, so that the substrate can no longer bind effectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active site binding is competitive inhibition. Non-competitive inhibition decreases, not increases, substrate binding. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme, not the substrate.

questions.question_text: An antagonist drug works by:

options.text: Mimicking the natural messenger and activating the receptor
Binding to the receptor without activating it, blocking the natural messenger
Increasing the production of natural messenger

questions.explanation_correct: An antagonist binds to the receptor site but does not activate it. By occupying the binding site, it prevents the natural chemical messenger from binding, thereby blocking the biological response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Activating the receptor is agonist action. Antagonists do not destroy receptors or increase messenger production. They simply block the receptor.

questions.question_text: Non-narcotic analgesics like aspirin relieve pain by:

options.text: Acting on the central nervous system
Inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins which cause pain and inflammation

questions.explanation_correct: Aspirin and other non-narcotic analgesics inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is required for prostaglandin synthesis. Since prostaglandins cause pain, inflammation, and fever, blocking their production relieves these symptoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acting on CNS is the mechanism of narcotic analgesics. They do not completely block nerve transmission. They do not induce sleep (that would be a sedative/hypnotic).

questions.question_text: Drugs can be classified on the basis of their molecular targets. Which of the following is NOT a common drug target?
questions.explanation_correct: Noble gases are inert and are not biological macromolecular targets for drugs. Common drug targets include enzymes, receptors, carrier proteins, nucleic acids, and ion channels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzymes, receptors, and nucleic acids are all established drug targets. Many drugs work by interacting with these biological macromolecules.

questions.question_text: The therapeutic effect of a drug depends on:

options.text: Its three-dimensional shape, which determines binding to the target site

questions.explanation_correct: The therapeutic effect of a drug depends on its three-dimensional shape and chemical properties, which determine how well it fits into the binding site of its target (enzyme active site or receptor). This is the lock-and-key concept in drug action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Molecular formula alone does not determine activity (isomers can have different activities). Colour, taste, and molecular mass are not the primary determinants of drug-target binding.

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes the concept of drug synergism?

options.text: Two drugs cancel each other's effects
Two drugs together produce an effect greater than the sum of their individual effects
A drug becomes toxic at high doses
A drug has no effect on the patient

questions.explanation_correct: Drug synergism occurs when two drugs used together produce an enhanced effect that is greater than the sum of their individual effects. This is important in combination therapy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drugs cancelling each other is antagonism. Toxicity at high doses is an adverse effect. No effect describes drug resistance or placebo effect.

questions.question_text: Histamine is a chemical messenger that stimulates acid secretion in the stomach. Ranitidine is used to treat peptic ulcers because it:

options.text: Blocks H2 histamine receptors, reducing acid secretion
Stimulates production of protective mucus only

questions.explanation_correct: Ranitidine is an H2 receptor antagonist. It blocks histamine H2 receptors on parietal cells in the stomach lining, preventing histamine from stimulating acid secretion, thus reducing stomach acid production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neutralising acid directly is the action of antacids. Killing H. pylori requires specific antibiotics. Ranitidine does not primarily stimulate mucus production.

questions.question_text: Sodium benzoate is used in food as:
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium benzoate (C6H5COONa) is the most commonly used food preservative. It inhibits the growth of yeasts, moulds, and some bacteria, especially in acidic foods like jams, pickles, and carbonated drinks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Artificial sweeteners include aspartame and saccharin. Antioxidants include BHT and BHA. Sodium benzoate is specifically a preservative that prevents microbial spoilage.

questions.question_text: Aspartame is:

options.text: An artificial sweetener about 200 times sweeter than sucrose

questions.explanation_correct: Aspartame is an artificial sweetener (methyl ester of a dipeptide of aspartic acid and phenylalanine) that is approximately 200 times sweeter than sucrose. It is used in diet drinks, sugar-free products, and by diabetics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aspartame is not a preservative, antioxidant, or colouring agent. It is specifically a low-calorie artificial sweetener.

questions.question_text: Soaps are sodium or potassium salts of:
questions.explanation_correct: Soaps are sodium (hard soap) or potassium (soft soap) salts of long-chain fatty acids like stearic acid (C17H35COOH), palmitic acid (C15H31COOH), and oleic acid (C17H33COOH).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Long-chain alcohols are not soap precursors. Alkyl sulphates are synthetic detergents. Short-chain carboxylic acids would not have the surfactant properties needed for cleansing.

questions.question_text: Soaps do not work well in hard water because:

options.text: Hard water is too hot for soap
Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions in hard water form insoluble precipitates (scum) with soap
Hard water has too high a pH
Soap dissolves too quickly in hard water

questions.explanation_correct: Hard water contains Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions. These react with the fatty acid anions in soap to form insoluble calcium/magnesium salts (scum): 2C17H35COO-Na+ + Ca2+ gives (C17H35COO)2Ca (precipitate). This wastes soap and reduces lathering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hard water temperature is not the issue. pH is not the primary factor. Soap does not dissolve too quickly; it precipitates with Ca/Mg ions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an antioxidant used in food?
questions.explanation_correct: BHT (butylated hydroxytoluene) is a synthetic antioxidant added to food (especially fats and oils) to prevent oxidative rancidity. BHA (butylated hydroxyanisole) is another common food antioxidant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium benzoate is a preservative. Saccharin and aspartame are artificial sweeteners. BHT specifically prevents oxidation of food components.

questions.question_text: Synthetic detergents work better than soaps in hard water because:

options.text: Their calcium and magnesium salts are soluble in water

questions.explanation_correct: Synthetic detergents (alkyl sulphates/sulphonates) form calcium and magnesium salts that are soluble in water, unlike soaps which form insoluble scum. Therefore, detergents lather and clean effectively even in hard water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Concentration is not the key factor. Having more hydrocarbon chains would not help. Detergents are synthetic, not natural. The solubility of their Ca/Mg salts is the crucial difference.

questions.question_text: The cleansing action of soap involves the formation of:

options.text: Micelles in which the non-polar tail dissolves in grease and the polar head faces water

questions.explanation_correct: Soap molecules form micelles in water. The non-polar hydrocarbon tails dissolve in grease/oil (like dissolves like), while the polar carboxylate heads face outward into the water. This emulsifies the grease, which is then washed away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soap does not form covalent bonds with dirt or ionic bonds with water. It does not precipitate dirt. Micelle formation is the key mechanism of cleansing.

questions.question_text: Biodegradable detergents have:
questions.explanation_correct: Biodegradable detergents have straight-chain (linear) hydrocarbon tails that can be easily broken down by microorganisms. Branched-chain detergents are non-biodegradable because microbes cannot easily degrade branched structures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Branched chains resist biodegradation. Aromatic rings also reduce biodegradability. All detergents must have hydrocarbon chains for surfactant action.

questions.question_text: Saccharin is an artificial sweetener that is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Saccharin (ortho-sulphobenzimide) is approximately 550 times sweeter than sucrose. It is calorie-free and was the first artificial sweetener to be discovered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saccharin is much sweeter than 10 or 100 times. It is not the same sweetness as sucrose. Its extreme sweetness allows very small amounts to provide the desired taste.

questions.question_text: An anionic detergent is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium lauryl sulphate (CH3(CH2)11OSO3-Na+) is an anionic detergent. The large part of the molecule carrying the cleansing action is the anion (negatively charged sulphate group with the hydrocarbon tail).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium stearate is a soap, not a synthetic detergent. Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide is a cationic detergent (positive charge). Polyethylene glycol stearate is a non-ionic detergent.

questions.question_text: Saponification is the process of:

options.text: Alkaline hydrolysis of fats or oils to produce soap and glycerol

questions.explanation_correct: Saponification is the reaction of a fat or oil (triglyceride) with a strong alkali (NaOH or KOH) to produce soap (sodium/potassium salt of fatty acid) and glycerol. Fat + 3NaOH gives 3 soap molecules + glycerol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Detergent manufacturing from petroleum is a different industrial process. Protein hydrolysis gives amino acids. Fatty acid polymerisation does not occur in soap making.

questions.question_text: Cationic detergents are used as:
questions.explanation_correct: Cationic detergents (quaternary ammonium salts like cetyltrimethylammonium bromide) have bactericidal properties and are used as fabric softeners and germicides in hair conditioners and hospital disinfectants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dishwashing liquids typically use anionic detergents. Cationic detergents are not food preservatives or sweeteners. Their unique property is germicidal action combined with softening.

questions.question_text: Which drug is obtained from opium and is used as a strong pain reliever but is highly addictive?
questions.explanation_correct: Morphine is obtained from opium (the dried latex of Papaver somniferum). It is a powerful narcotic analgesic used for severe pain relief, but it is highly addictive and its use is strictly controlled.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aspirin, paracetamol, and ibuprofen are non-narcotic, non-addictive analgesics that are available over the counter. Only morphine is derived from opium.

questions.question_text: Drug-enzyme interaction is an example of which type of drug-target interaction?
questions.explanation_correct: Drug-enzyme interaction is a type of drug-protein interaction since enzymes are proteins. Drugs can bind to the active site (competitive inhibition) or allosteric site (non-competitive inhibition) of the enzyme.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drug-receptor interaction is a separate category. Drug-nucleic acid interaction involves drugs binding to DNA/RNA. Enzymes are proteins, so this falls under drug-protein interaction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a traditional food preservative used for centuries?
questions.explanation_correct: Common salt (NaCl) has been used for centuries as a traditional food preservative (salting of fish, meat, pickles). It preserves food by reducing water activity, making the environment unsuitable for microbial growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium benzoate, BHT, and potassium sorbate are modern chemical preservatives. Salt, sugar, vinegar, and oil are traditional preservatives used long before modern chemistry.

questions.question_text: Veronal and luminal are examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: Veronal (barbital) and luminal (phenobarbital) are barbiturate tranquilizers. Barbiturates are derivatives of barbituric acid and are used as sedatives, hypnotics, and anti-anxiety drugs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not pain relievers (analgesics), infection fighters (antibiotics), or wound cleaners (antiseptics). They are specifically barbiturate-type tranquilizers.

questions.question_text: Non-ionic detergents are formed from:

options.text: Sodium salts of long-chain fatty acids
Esters of high molecular mass alcohols with polyethylene glycol

questions.explanation_correct: Non-ionic detergents do not contain any charged group. They are typically esters of high molecular mass alcohols (like stearyl alcohol) with polyethylene glycol. The polyethylene oxide chain provides water solubility.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium salts of fatty acids are soaps. Quaternary ammonium salts are cationic detergents. Sodium alkyl sulphonates are anionic detergents.

questions.question_text: Why do different enantiomers of a drug sometimes have different therapeutic effects?

options.text: They have different three-dimensional shapes that interact differently with the chiral binding site on the target
They are made of different elements

questions.explanation_correct: Enantiomers are non-superimposable mirror images with different 3D orientations. Since drug targets (enzymes, receptors) are also chiral (made of L-amino acids), one enantiomer may fit the binding site perfectly while the other may not, leading to different therapeutic effects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enantiomers have the same molecular mass, same chemical formula, and are made of the same elements. Only their three-dimensional arrangement differs.

questions.question_text: Norethindrone is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Norethindrone is a synthetic progestogen used in oral contraceptive pills (antifertility drugs). It suppresses ovulation when combined with synthetic oestrogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Norethindrone is not an antibiotic, analgesic, or antihistamine. It is specifically a hormonal antifertility drug.

questions.question_text: Alitame is an artificial sweetener that is:

options.text: About 2000 times sweeter than sucrose and difficult to control sweetness of food
Exactly the same sweetness as sucrose

questions.explanation_correct: Alitame is an artificial sweetener approximately 2000 times sweeter than sucrose. Its extreme sweetness makes it difficult to control the sweetness level of foods, which limits its practical use.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alitame is much sweeter than sucrose, not less sweet or equal. It is 2000 times sweeter, not just 10 times.

questions.question_text: Oxidative rancidity of food containing fats and oils is prevented by adding:
questions.explanation_correct: Antioxidants like BHA (butylated hydroxyanisole) and BHT (butylated hydroxytoluene) are added to food containing fats and oils to prevent oxidative rancidity by scavenging free radicals that cause oxidation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Preservatives prevent microbial growth, not oxidation. Sweeteners add taste. Detergents are for cleaning. Only antioxidants specifically prevent oxidative degradation.

questions.question_text: The tincture of iodine used as an antiseptic is:

options.text: 2-3% solution of iodine in alcohol-water mixture

questions.explanation_correct: Tincture of iodine is a 2-3% solution of iodine in an alcohol-water mixture. It is applied to wounds and cuts as an antiseptic to prevent infection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not a purely aqueous solution (iodine is poorly soluble in water). It is not dissolved in acetone. Solid iodine is not applied directly to wounds.

questions.question_text: The term 'chemotherapy' refers to:

options.text: The use of chemicals (drugs) to treat diseases

questions.explanation_correct: Chemotherapy refers to the therapeutic use of chemical substances (drugs) to treat diseases. While commonly associated with cancer treatment, the term broadly encompasses all drug-based disease treatment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Physical therapy uses exercises. Chemical analysis is analytical chemistry. Manufacturing is industrial chemistry. Chemotherapy specifically means treating disease with chemicals/drugs.

questions.question_text: The process of making soap from fats and NaOH gives soap and:
questions.explanation_correct: Saponification: Fat (triglyceride) + 3NaOH gives 3 molecules of soap (sodium salt of fatty acid) + glycerol (propane-1,2,3-triol). Glycerol is the valuable by-product of soap manufacture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethanol is not a product of saponification. Fatty acids are already part of the fat molecule. Mineral oil is unrelated. Glycerol is specifically released when the ester bonds in the triglyceride are hydrolysed.

questions.question_text: Bithionol is added to soap as:

options.text: An antiseptic agent to prevent body odour caused by bacteria

questions.explanation_correct: Bithionol is added to soap as an antiseptic agent. It reduces body odour by killing the bacteria on skin that decompose sweat to produce odorous compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bithionol is not a fragrance, softener, or bleach. Its function is specifically antiseptic/antibacterial.

questions.question_text: Which of the following artificial sweeteners is unsuitable for cooking because it decomposes at high temperatures?
questions.explanation_correct: Aspartame (a dipeptide methyl ester) is unstable at high temperatures and decomposes when heated, losing its sweetness. Therefore, it is not suitable for use in baking or cooking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saccharin and sucralose are heat-stable and can be used in cooking. Alitame is also relatively stable. Aspartame is specifically sensitive to heat due to its peptide bonds.

questions.question_text: A micelle formed by soap in water has:

options.text: Polar heads pointing inward and non-polar tails pointing outward
Non-polar hydrocarbon tails pointing inward and polar carboxylate heads pointing outward toward water
All molecules arranged in a flat sheet

questions.explanation_correct: In a micelle, soap molecules arrange themselves with their non-polar hydrocarbon tails pointing inward (away from water, forming a hydrophobic core) and their polar carboxylate heads pointing outward toward the surrounding water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polar heads pointing inward would be energetically unfavourable in water. Soap molecules do not form flat sheets in water. The arrangement is highly organised, not random.
